loans.use: to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor

loans.name: Martina

texts.en:
Martina is taking a loan of $600.00 to improve her business. She is running a kiosk that helps her to generate income for her family. 

She will use the loan to buy stocks to keep in her store such as buying and selling of pigs. She opened her business  a year ago with her own working capital of $400.00.  Martina is a hard working woman and she hopes to run a bigger business in the future.

loans.use: To buy and sell pigs

loans.name: Lubov

texts.ru:
Любовь — предприниматель из Павлограда. Она предоставляет парикмахерские услуги в своем салоне, который открыла в 2007 году. Среди услуг, которые предоставляются в ее салоне — маникюр, педикюр, женские и мужские стрижки, укладки и т. п. Любовь очень гордится тем, что смогла открыть свое дело. Она получает удовольствие от работы. 
Сумма в 30 000 гривен нужна Любови для того, чтобы закупить материалы, инструменты для работы и провести небольшие ремонтные работы в парикмахерской. Любови для работы нужны краски, окислители, лаки и гели-лаки, гели для наращивания ногтей, стерилизаторы для ногтей, а также машинки для мужских стрижек. Относительно ремонтных работ, то это, в основном, касается установки вентиляции и замены водопровода для подачи горячей воды.
texts.en:
Lubov is a hairdresser from Lavlograd. She offers beauty services at her own salon, which she opened in 2007. Among the services available at her salon are manicures, pedicures, women's and men's haircuts, styling, etc. Lubov is very proud of the fact that she was able to open her own business. She gets enjoyment from her work.

Lubov needs 30,000 hryvnas to buy materials and instruments for her work and to make some small repairs to her salon. For her work, she needs hair dyes, oxidants, nail varnish and polish, gel for acrylic nails, sterilizer for her nail clippers, and electric clippers for men's haircuts. The purpose of her repairs is to install ventilation and to purchase a new boiler for her hot water supply.

loans.use: to purchase a heater for her retail space

loans.name: Resty

texts.en:
Resty is 24 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. She has two children with one of them currently in school. For the past three years, Resty has been working hard to manage her salon, which does hair dressing. 

To help expand her business, Resty has requested a loan of 800,000 Ugandan Shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more hair relaxers for attracting more clients, and it will help Resty to generate greater profits to take good care of her children. Resty hopes that in the future she will be able to build a residential house. 

Resty is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to purchase more hair relaxers for attracting more clients

loans.name: Sherwin

texts.en:
Sherwin has been  providing motorcycle transport services that carry passengers and baggage for more than six years to earn a living. 

He also has a farm, their main source of income. With his income, his previous loans, used for his activities, were successfully repaid.   Recently, Sherwin took a new loan to purchase fertilizer such as manure to add improvements to his farm. He dreams to have a better living in the future.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en: Lilia has been operating her own retail store for six years and she earns well from this. With her generated revenue, she was able to repay her previous loan successfully. She operates a service-based business in their community. To improve  sales, she took a new loan from GDMPC micro credit to purchase additional grocery goods to sell. Having two children requires more efforts to provide for their needs, especially their future education. In the future, Lilia hopes to improve the general living conditions of the her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional grocery goods to sell

loans.name: Dorrington

texts.en:
Dorrington is a married man; he has two children. He describes himself to be spiritual. 

He operates a retail business where he sells electronics, and he has been involved in this business for 12 years. His business is located in an urban area, and his primary customers are the general public. He describes his biggest business challenge to be a lack of capital. 

He will use the Kes 70,000 loan to buy more stock of electronics. 

His business goal is to expand within five years. He hopes that in the future, he will be prosperous. 

This is his second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. The previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more stock of electronics

loans.name: Fred

texts.en: Fred is a 28-year-old married man who has four children. He describes himself as focused. He operates a business where he transports customers using a tuk tuk (auto rickshaw). He has been involved in this business for three years. His business is located in an urban area and his primary customers are the general public. He describes his biggest business challenge to be insecurity. He will use the KES 80,000 loan to buy a second-hand tuk tuk. His business goal is to have three tuk tuks within five years. He hopes that in the future, he will be at peace. This is his second loan with SMEP Micro finance Bank. He will use the anticipated profits to reinvest in the business.

loans.use: to buy a second-hand tuk tuk (auto rickshaw) for his transport business.

loans.name: Mujeres Del Barrio Group

texts.es: Eduviges tiene 62 años de edad, (es la que aparece en la foto de último de izquierda a derecha de blusa blanca y delantal a cuadros) vive en el municipio de San Antonio, departamento de Suchitepéquez, tiene una hija de 24 años de edad trabaja en un almacén de ropa, ella se dedica a la preparación de tamales y los vende en la comunidad donde vive, comenta que le deja buena ganancia y tiene 7 años de estar vendiendo, Eduviges necesita un crédito para comprar insumos (arroz, clavos de olor, chile pimienta entre otros) para la preparación de tamales, ella tiene planeado construir una casa para mejorar las condiciones su vida y la de su familia.
texts.en:
Eduviges is 62 years of age (she is the one who appears in the photo last from left to right in a white top and flannel apron) and lives in the San Antonio municipality, department of Suchitepéquez. She has a daughter who is 24 years old who works in a clothing department store. She earns a living preparing tamales and sells them in the community where she lives. She comments that it leaves her with a good income, and she has been selling them for 7 years. 

Eduviges needs a loan to buy supplies (rice, cloves, bell peppers, among others) for preparing tamales. She has plans to build a house to improve her living conditions and those of her family.

loans.use: to buy supplies for the preparation of tamales.

loans.name: Thelma

texts.en:
Thelma works hard to support her family. On November 8, 2013, her business and home were wiped out by super typhoon Haiyan.

She has restarted her general store business and been with NWTF since 2007.  

She is now requesting a PHP 10,000 housing loan through NWTF to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor so she could build a house for her family.

With your help, Thelma will be able to rebuild her devastated life sooner.

Thelma would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor

loans.name: Tam

texts.en:
Tam, 51, is a breadwinner in the family consisting of seven children. She lives in Battambang province as a local farmer and a vegetable grower. Besides this agribusiness, she uses her free time to work for others for a fee. This business earns her about 35,000 KHR per day. 

With Kiva’s partner, VisionFund, Tam has been in 13 loan cycles with a successful repayment of her past loans which improved her lifestyle in a gradual pace. Now she is seeking for a new loan of 1,500,000 KHR in order to buy a cow and to buy seed to support her farming business. She hopes that she can earn more income.

loans.use: To buy a cow and to buy seed

loans.name: Viola

texts.en:
Viola is 19 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past two years, she has been working hard to manage her retail shop, where she sells essential commodities. 

To help expand her business, Viola has requested a loan for 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. She will use the loan to buy more essential goods like sugar and salt for her business, because this will allow her to increase her profits and further expand her business. Viola hopes that in the future she will be able to build rental houses. 

Viola is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more essential goods like sugar and salt for her business,

loans.name: Alfred

texts.en: Alfred is married and has 4 children. He describes himself to be honest. For the past 12 years, Alfred has operated a farm where he grows maize. His business is located in a viable location and his primary customers are local residents. He describes his biggest business challenge to be lack of capital. Alfred will use the KES 70,000 loan to buy fertilizer and seeds. His business goal is to be successful within 5 years. Alfred hopes that, in the future, he will be stable. This is his fourth loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Alfred will use the anticipated profits to pay school fees and household bills.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seeds

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia is thankful for the financial assistance extended to her as she was able to buy more products for her food stall. Her loan helped not just in her business but also in the education of her children. Her income from business is assisting their everyday household expenditures. She and her husband are working hard to provide for their everyday needs.
 
Alicia would like to apply for another 40,000 PHP loan to purchase raw ingredients such as rice, pork, chicken, vegetables and products needed in her business. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs and the educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Alicia dreams of expanding her business and having another stall. She hopes to give her children a good life and education. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week, and this is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for raw ingredients such as rice, pork, chicken, vegetables and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Valeriana

texts.en:
Valeriana works hard to support her family. On November 8, 2013, her business and home were wiped out by Super Typhoon Haiyan.

Valeriana has been in NWTF since 2012 and has restarted her general store business. She is now requesting a PHP 10,000 housing loan through NWTF to purchase building materials and pay for construction labour so that she can build a house for her family.

With your help, Valeriana will be able to rebuild her devastated life sooner.

In the future, Valeriana would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase building materials and pay for construction labour

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
Wilma, 60 years old, is married and has five children. She works very hard to provide for them. Wilma's business and family home was destroyed by super typhoon Haiyan, which swept through the Philippines last November 8, 2013. Wilma has restarted her fish vending business and now needs to provide her family with safe shelter.

Wilma has taken a PHP 9,500 housing loan through NWTF to purchase materials and to pay for construction labor to rebuild her family home. Wilma is committed to rebuilding her devastated life and would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase building materials and to pay for construction labor

loans.name: Theary's Group

texts.en: Theary is 35 years old and a mother blessed with two young children. She iives in the Kam Rieng district of Battambang province, where she grows rice. She supplements her income by working for others for a wage. Theary has taken out and repaid two prior loans from VisionFund (Kiva’s partner), and used both to slowly improve her family's lifestyle. For this cycle, she has joined a two-person loan group. As the leader, she will spend her entire portion to pay for plowing fees and rice seed. She hopes that she can successfully replant her crop and earn a good return from her work.

loans.use: to pay for plowing fees and rice seed.

loans.name: Leap's Group

texts.en: Leap was born in the Moung Russey district of Battambang province, and is the 54-year-old mother of six children, one of whom is in school. She covers her expenses by rainy-season paddy-rice farming on two-and-a-half hectares and supplements this income by working for others. The business that she has had for 15 years earns almost 40,000 KHR per day. She has taken out and repaid three prior loans, and is now part of a two-person group which is requesting a loan from Kiva partner VisionFund. Leap made good use of her prior loans to improve her family's life, and she and her other loan group member are now requesting 1,400,000 KHR each. As a leader, she will use her funds to buy fertilizer, insecticide, and to pay for labor. She hopes that she can improve her yield from last year's level.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and insecticide, and to pay labor costs.

loans.name: Babrah

texts.en:
Babrah is 18 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past year, Babrah has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells essential commodities. 

To help expand her business, Babrah has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more items, such as sugar and salt, to resell and will help Babrah to generate greater profits and improve her family's standard of living. Babrah hopes that, in the future, she will be able to open up a wholesale shop. 

Babrah is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to purchase more items, such as sugar and salt, to resell

loans.name: Jalia

texts.en:
Jalia is 18 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. She has one child. For the past 2 years, Jalia has been working hard to manage her boutique, which sells first-class clothes. 

To help expand her business, Jalia has requested a loan of 700,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more children's and ladies' clothes to sell, and will help Jalia to generate greater profits and take good care of her child and herself. Jalia hopes that, in the future, she will be able to buy a plot of land. 

Jalia is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more children's and ladies' clothes to sell

loans.name: Luis Antonio

texts.es: Luis Antonio es un pequeño comerciante, tiene una pulpería en su casa de habitación. Hace algunos años, uniendo fuerzas con su esposa logró poner la pulpería con dinero propio, y a través de créditos han ido invirtiendo en el negocio. La pulpería es administrada en conjunto con su esposa. Tiene dos hijos que asisten a la escuela, la educación la obtienen de la ganancia de la pulpería. El crédito solicitado será para comprar granos básicos y productos de limpieza. Y así poder abastecer su negocio, y mantener la variedad de la oferta para sus clientes.
texts.en: Luis Antonio is a small merchant who has a convenience store in his home.  Some years ago he and his wife joined forces to set up the store with their own money and through the help of loans that they invested into their business.  He and his wife manage the store together.  He has two children who attend school and he pays for their education with the profits from the store.  He will use the money from this loan to buy basic grains and cleaning products so he can stock his business and maintain a variety of products for his customers.

loans.use: to stock his store.

loans.name: Falidah

texts.en:
Falidah is 22 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has 3 children, 2 of them currently in school. For the past 2 years, Falidah has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells essential commodities. 

To help expand her business, Falidah has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more essential goods, such as sugar and salt, and will help Falidah to generate greater profits and to pay school fees for her children. Falidah hopes that, in the future, she will be able to build a residential house. 

Falidah is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more essential goods, such as sugar and salt

loans.name: Ana Pastora

texts.es: Doña Ana se dedica a la venta de calzado y bisutería, y está solicitando el crédito para invertir en su negocio, y así poder aumentar la variedad de estilos que ofrece en calzado. Doña Ana es madre soltera de 6 hijos, quiénes son mayores de edad e independientes a ella. Los créditos anteriores los había utilizado para mejorar su vivienda, y ahora está en la necesidad de invertir en su negocio para aumentar los ingresos para sustentar a su familia.
texts.en: Ana sells shoes and costume jewelry and is asking for this loan to invest in her business so she can increase the variety and styles of shoes she sells.  Ana is a single mother and has adult six children on their own.  She used the money from the previous loans to increase her family income to support her family.

loans.use: to buy shoes and costume jewelry.

loans.name: Señor De Huanca De San Jeronimo Group

texts.es:
Los socios pertenecen al banco comunal “SEÑOR DE HUANCA DE SAN JERONIMO”; Este banco se ubicada en el distrito de San Jeronimo, perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Victoria ella es conviviente y tiene 53 años y tiene 6 hijos; La socia trabaja en su negocio de venta y crianza de animales, la socia cría los cuyes y gallinas los hace crecer y engordar y luego los vende en las diferentes ferias, por medio de este pequeño negocio la socia saca adelante a sus hijos, el sueño de la socia es tener un local donde pueda vender los cuyes y gallinas. La socia solicita el crédito para comprar cuyes y gallinas y alimentos para los cuyes y gallinas.

Los socios que están pegados a la foto grupal se les tomo la foto después de la reunión porque pidieron permiso por motivos de trabajo.

 
Los otros socios se dedican al negocio de venta de artesanía, negocio de venta de animales, negocio de tienda de abarrotes y negocio de venta de verduras.



La socia agradece a quienes forman parte de este sueño mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
San Jeronimo, within the Cusco, province, and department.  Victoria is 53 years old, in a relationship, and has six children.  She sells and raises animals and raises Guinea pigs, and chickens.  She raises them and then sells them at the various fairs and supports her children through this business.  Her dream is to have a shop where she can sell her Guinea pigs and chickens.  She is asking for this loan to buy Guinea pigs, chickens, and feed.

The members with their pictures pasted onto the larger photo were not able to attend the group photo session due to work commitments.

The other members sell crafts, animals, groceries, and vegetables.

She is grateful to those who form part of this dream and is committed to making her payments on time.

loans.use: to buy small animals and feed.

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal SANTA BEATRIZ, el banco esta ubicad en el distrito de Maranura, provincia de La Convención y departamento de Cusco.
La socia María tiene 41 años de edad tiene 02 hijos y es soltera, la socia alterna sus actividades diarias dedicándose a la agricultura, la socia lleva buen tiempo dedicándose  a este negocio el cual le va bien gracias al empeño que le pone cada di a su negocio, la socia es una persona responsable y empeñosa, la socia desea poder seguir trabajando para de esta manera seguir apoyando a si familia.
La socia solicito el crédito para la compra de semillas, abono entre otros.
La socia se siente agradecida con el crédito otorgado y se compromete a cumplir con sus cuotas establecidas.
texts.en:
She is a member of the SANTA BEATRIZ communal bank, located in the Maranura district, within the La Convencion province and the Cusco department.

Maria is 41 years old and has two children.  She is single and has been working as a farmer for some time.  Things are going well for her thanks to the dedication she puts into her business each day.  She is a hardworking and responsible person who wants to continue to work so she can continue supporting her family.  She is asking for this loan to buy compost and other things.

She is grateful for the loan and is committed to making her payments on time.

loans.use: to buy farming supplies.

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita is 57 years old and married with six children. 

Rosita and her family survived super typhoon Haiyan which swept through the Philippines last November 8, 2013, but her business and family home were wiped out. 

Rosita is taking out a housing loan amounting 5,500 PHP to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor to build a house for her family. 

Rosita has been an NWTF borrower since 2012 and plans to recover through her fishing business.

With your help, Rosita can rebuild her house and rebound from the devastation of super typhoon Haiyan. She would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor

loans.name: Jose Mari

texts.en:
Jose Mari is a resident of Silang, Cavite, Philippines. He is 46 years old, married to Aileen (an OFW) and a father of three. By the grace of God, Jose Mari has managed to support his children's schooling. He works hard to continually send his children to school to finish their studies.

Jose Mari oversees operations of their jeepney (see footnote) transportation business. They have a jeepney with a capacity of 18 people, who all pay a boundary (daily quota) each day. 

To help him continue operations of his business, Jose Mari is requesting a PHP 10,000 loan to buy new tires for the jeepney and to renew his registration. He expects a boost in his business income as he expands his business.  

Jose Mari dreams of a better and brighter future for his children. He hopes that someday his family will be again complete and that there will be no need for his wife to work abroad anymore. Jose Mari meets up with his co-fellowship members to share stories of his work every week.

-Curiously, Jeepneys have purely American origins. They were first used by American soldiers helping the Philippines throw off the invading Japanese. Filipino ingenuity, however, managed to see this vehicle as an opportunity to earn, and modified the Jeep into a 20-seater jeepney, open enough to provide adequate ventilation, sturdy for every day travel, and cheap enough to buy and maintain. Now, the jeepneys are one of the things that makes the Philippines truly Philippines.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for spare parts and maintenance of their jeepney unit.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to develop a well, buy small fish and seeds and agricultural supplies

loans.name: Eduardo Santos

texts.es:
Este es Eduardo, un hombre humilde y trabajador que se gana la vida con el trabajo duro de la agricultura.
El alquila terrenos para cultivar sus propios cultivos y tener los ingresos necesarios para sostener a sus padres que ya están avanzados en edad.

Su mayor sueño es tener su propia parcela de tierra y así obtener más utilidades, pero por ahora necesita un auxilio para alquilar un terreno, comprar insumos agropecuarios y para la preparación de la tierra, de este modo podrá conseguir unos cultivos sanos y aumentar sus ingresos familiares, teniendo como objetivo el mejorar la calidad de vida de su hogar.
texts.en:
This is Eduardo, a humble and hardworking man who earns a living in the tough field of agriculture.  He rents plots of land to cultivate his own crops and earn the necessary income to support his aging parents.  

His greatest dream is to have his own piece of land and to obtain higher profits, but right now he needs a loan to rent a plot of land, buy agricultural products and to prepare the soil.  In this way, he will be able to raise healthy crops and increase his household income, as he has the goal of improving the quality of life for his family.

loans.use: to rent a plot of land and to buy agricultural supplies to prepare the soil

loans.name: Phea's Group

texts.en: Phea, a villager from Bovel district of Battambang province, is the young mother of two schoolchildren. She is a local farmer who grows rice and cassava as her main sources of income. Additionally, she works for others for a fee. Her current business earns about 27,000 KHR per day to cover her family's costs. Phea, who has taken out and repaid loans in the past, has joined with another borrower to request a new loan for 1,200,000 KHR for herself and the same amount for the group's other member. As the leader, she will spend her entire loan portion to pay for plowing fees for her paddy-rice and cassava field. She hopes that this financial aid will allow her to be ready for upcoming replanting season so as she can earn enough money to keep her children in school.

loans.use: to pay plowing fees.

loans.name: Elma

texts.en:
Elma, 32 years old, is married and has three children, two of them currently in school. Elma works very hard to provide for them. Elma's business and family home was destroyed by super typhoon Haiyan, which swept through the Philippines last November 8, 2013. Elma has restarted her fish vending business and now needs to provide her family with safe shelter.

Elma has taken a PHP 10,000 housing loan through NWTF to purchase materials and to pay for construction labor to rebuild her family home. Elma is committed to rebuilding her devastated life and would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase building materials and to pay for construction labor

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy seed potatoes and agricultural products that will help protect them

loans.name: Phalla's Group

texts.en: Aged 44 and a resident from Tbaung Khmum district of Kampong Cham province, Phalla is a married mother blessed with five children. Currently, she still needs to support her two kids who remain in school. For several years involved in her current business, she can earn up 44,400 KHR per day to support her big household. This is the third loan for her and first loan for her co-borrower with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). She has repaid her past loan completely and it has helped her to improve her livelihood better than before. Now, she is seeking 1,000,000 KHR and her joint borrower is applying for 600,000 KHR. As the leader, Phalla will spend her loan portion to pay for plowing fee, labor cost, reaping fee, and to buy fertilizer plus insecticide for her crop. She truly believes that she can make her yield better than before.

loans.use: To pay for plowing fee, labor cost, reaping fee, and to buy fertilizer plus insecticide

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Tbaung Khmum district

loans.name: Safia

texts.en:
Safia is 40 years old and lives in the town of Bombo in the Luwero region of Uganda. She is married and has 3 children who are all currently in school. For the past 10 years, Safia has been working hard to manage her retail shop which sells general merchandise. 

To help expand her business, Safia has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more plates, cups, thermos warmers and other items to sell, and will help Safia to generate greater profits, save and help her pay school fees for her children. Safia hopes that in the future she will be able to expand the business into a whole sale shop. 

Safia is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Safia who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more plates, cups, thermos warmers and other items to sell

loans.name: Noor

texts.en:
Noor is 21 years old and lives in the town of Bombo in the Luwero region of Uganda. For the past 2 years, Noor has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells motor spare parts. 

To help expand his business, Noor has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more motor tyres and tubes for sale, and will help Noor to generate greater profits and improve on his family's standards of living. Noor hopes that in the future he will be able to add more and different items for sale. 

Noor is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Noor who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more motor tyres and tubes to sell

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is 23 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. For the past 3 years, Sarah has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells soft drinks. 

To help expand her business, Sarah has requested a loan of 900,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more sodas, water and juice, and will help Sarah to generate greater profits and to take care of some of her family's basic needs. Sarah hopes that, in the future, she will be able to build a residential house. 

SARAH is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more sodas, water and juice

loans.name: Cate

texts.en:
Cate is 22 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. She has one child. For the past year, Cate has been working hard to manage her craft shop, which sells handicraft items. 

To help expand her business, Cate has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more materials to make crafts and will help Cate to generate greater profits and to take care of her child. Cate hopes that, in the future, she will be able to open up a retail shop. 

Cate is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more materials to make crafts

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is 48 years old and lives in the town of Bombo in the Luwero region of Uganda. She is married, and has eight children with three of them currently in school. For the past 10 years, Lydia has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells essential commodities. 

To help expand her business, Lydia has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more essential goods like sugar and salt for the business, and will help Lydia to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children. 

Lydia hopes that in the future she will be able to create other sources of income. 

Lydia is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Lydia who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more essential goods like sugar and salt for the business

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet is 24 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has two children who are both currently in school. For the past three years, Annet has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells essential goods. 

To help expand her business, Annet has requested a loan of 900,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more essential goods like sugar and salt for the business, and will help Annet to generate greater profits and improve her family's standard of living. Annet hopes that in the future she will be able to build rental houses. 

Annet is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more essential goods like sugar and salt for the business

loans.name: Metian

texts.en:
Metian is a 38-year-old woman who is a widow and has six children whom she is taking care of. Since the demise of her husband, Metian has taken on the role of the sole provider and runs a dairy farming business which has been in operation for the last 20 years, earning an income of KES.14,200 every month. 

Metian is servicing her first loan of KES. 20,000 from VisionFund Kenya and intends to use this amount to buy additional healthy animal feed for her cattle in order to have more dairy produce to cater for her clients' needs. 

She plans to use the anticipated income to provide the best education to her children and hopes to have bright future with a lot of success.

loans.use: To buy more additional cattle feed in order to produce more milk for her clients

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to add new food services (lunch and soup) and to replenish beverages

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en:
Caroline is a 31-year-old woman who is married to Malachi and, together, they are blessed with four school-going children, ages between 14 and seven years. She has been in the motorcycle transport business for the last eight years, making a monthly profit of KES 10,000 (Kenya shillings). 

Caroline has applied for her first loan with VisionFund Kenya, to buy spare parts for her motorcycle. She plans to use the anticipated income to expand her business and to educate her children.

Caroline hopes to have a bright future and also to educate her children to a high level of education.

loans.use: to buy spare parts for her motorcycle transport business.

loans.name: Benkadi 2 Group

texts.fr:
Les 10 membres du groupe BENKADI 2 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 42 ans et ont en moyenne 3 enfants et vivant la plupart  dans des  familles traditionnelles à FATIA un village dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur septième prêt de campagne avec l’institution de microfinance soro yiriwaso, les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est  le mil  avec madame ADIARA débout au milieu sur la photo dans ce groupe de femme BENKADI 2. 
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter 2 sacs de 50 kg d’engrais, 2 bidons d’herbicide et payer les frais de labour  pour entretenir  0,75 hectare. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village et à SIKASSO à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femme au comptant et à crédit. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de  100 000 FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer d’une part son prêt et son intérêt et d’autre part aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en: The ten members of the Benkadi 2 Group are married women with an average age of 42 and an average of three children each. The majority of them live within traditional family frameworks in Fatia, a village in Sikasso Cercle, the third administrative region of Mali. They are collaborating with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution so that they can see through their agricultural activities during the winter period. This is their seventh loan with Soro Yiriwaso, with whom their previous loans were paid back in full. The group's main produce is millet. The group's representative is Adiara, the woman standing in the centre of the back row in the photo taken of the entire Benkadi 2 Group. With this loan, she is planning on buying two 50-kg sacks of fertiliser and two cans of herbicide, as well as paying for the labour costs to maintain three-quarters of a hectare of land. After the harvest, the produce is sold on a village level as well as in Sikasso to a customer base made up of both men and woman, accepting both credit and cash as payment. She is planning on making an average profit of 100,000 FCFA per season. These profits will allow her to pay off part of the loan and its interest and to also help her husband with their family's daily living expenses.

loans.use: to pay for fertiliser, labour costs and farming inputs

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en: Mariam is married and the mother of five children. She describes herself as determined, and operates a business where she sells poultry. She has been involved in this business for ten years and works out of a great location with many customers are of all types. She describes her biggest business challenge as a lack of capital. She will use this Kes 50,000 loan to buy chicks. Her business goal is to own four cows within five years. This is her second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Her previous one was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy chicks.

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina previously accessed a 10,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for her children’s education and in their personal, household and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 15,000 PHP loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her inventory. The more items displayed at the store, the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from the business will definitely help sustain her family’s daily needs and her children’s education expenses. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Regina hopes her business will continue to flourish. She dreams that her children will all manage to finish their schooling. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week, and there she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her variety store

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
This is Elena, 40, a resident of Silang Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Remigio and mother to her children. She, together with her husband and children, manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Elena retails processed meat products. What she basically does is buy processed meat products from wholesalers and sells them per piece/pack with a profit. Products range from ham, hot dogs, processed pork and other products of the like. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low selling prices and the many options she offers. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a Php 15,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

Elena desires to put up another business and hopes to cover all her family's needs through her hard work. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and  draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more stock of frozen foods and other items to sell

loans.name: Hripsime

texts.en:
Hripsime is from Lorut village which is located in Lori region. She lives there with her husband and four children (ages 7, 6, and twins who are only one year old). 

Hripsime and her husband are farmers. They both work hard, struggling for their everyday living. They are involved in breeding livestock consisting of cows, calves, and chickens, and in cultivation of potatoes and some grass. They sell the agricultural produce in the local market, which is an important source of the family’s income. 

To continue running her agricultural business in a sustainable way, Hripsime  needs a loan of USD 2000 to purchase a truck to transport the gathered harvest to nearby communities' markets. Hripsime and her family rely on the goodwill of the lenders and will be very thankful to them for their support.

loans.use: to purchase a truck to transport the harvest to the market

loans.name: Harim Adiel

texts.es:
Harim quedo impactado viendo  en la televisión las carreras internaciones y nacionales de ciclismo. Esta fue suficiente motivación que lo llevó a  dedicarse a la profesión de mecánico en bicicletas. Por el momento el negocio marcha de maravilla. A pesar de ser muy joven, su local ya goza de prestigio gracias a su eficiencia en los trabajos que realiza. 
KIVA MiCrédito es un motor necesario que lo impulsa para continuar su camino hacia el éxito.  Cada día aumenta el público que lo visita en su local. Harim por supuesto, desea satisfacer las necesidades de todos sus visitantes. Él solicitó otro préstamo, en la misma institución,  para invertir en la compra de llantas, aceites, lubricantes, pinturas, cadenas y  repuestos, que requiere para reparar las bicicletas de los clientes.
texts.en:
Harim was impacted by watching international and national bicycle races on television.  This was sufficient motivation to push him to dedicate himself to a profession as a bicycle mechanic.  For the moment, his business is running wonderfully.  Despite his young age, his shop already enjoys prestige thanks to his efficient work in the jobs he has done.

KIVA MiCredito is the indispensable engine that has pushed him to continue his journey to success.  Each day, the people who visit him in his shop grow.  Of course, Harim wants to satisfy the needs of all his clients.  He has requested another loan, through the same institution, to invest in the purchase of tires, oil, lubricants, paints, chains and spare parts that he needs to repair the bicycles of his clients.

loans.use: to buy tires, oil, lubricants, paint, chains and spare parts.

loans.name: Alvard

texts.en:
Alvard is an agronomist from Shirakamut village of Lori region. She lives with her son, as her husband and elder son are migrant workers. They left the country last year with the hope of finding a well paying job. 

Alvard is engaged in cattle breeding, in aviculture, in breeding a livestock of pigs, piglets and sheep, and in the cultivation of wheat. They sell the agricultural products in the local market, which is the most important source of the family's income. 

Now Alvard needs to prepare her agribusiness for this fruitful season. For that reason, she needs a loan of USD 2,000 to purchase forage (sawdust) for the livestock, and to buy six calves. The loan will help her sustain her agribusiness. 

Alvard and her family highly rely on the good will of the lenders, and will appreciate their support in collecting the needed loan.

loans.use: to pay for six calves and forage for the livestock

loans.name: Sumsun

texts.en:
Sumsun is a very young woman of only 25 years.  She is from the small village of Kholaigram in Jalpaiguri district. She is married and a housewife. Her family consists of her husband Saifuddin and four children.  Three of them are students in different grades in secondary level; one is grown up and unemployed.  Both Sumsun and her husband are illiterate and can sign their names only.

Susun's husband makes living by cultivating vegetables.  He grows varieties of vegetables like potatoes, bottle gourds, beans, chilies etc.  He has been working in agriculture over 10 years and has a lot of valuable experience that allows him to have always the best harvests. The farmland is an accessible location, suitable for farming and with fertile soil. Everything he produces, he sells all around the community and already has many customers, so people know that everything he sells is of top quality and at affordable prices. Now to meet customer demand and earn additional profit, he wants to cultivate tomatoes, but he lacks the working capital.

So, Sumsun wants to help him by taking a loan from BJS ( Kiva's partner).  The loan would allow her to purchase seeds, manure and pesticides to cultivate tomatoes. She hopes to earn a satisfactory profit from this new crop to upgrade their present financial condition and fulfill her dreams of giving proper education to her children and constructing a better house.

Her full thanks go to BJS and Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, manure and pesticides to cultivate tomatoes.

loans.name: Kea's Group

texts.en:
Kea, a mother of two children, is 60 years old and a villager from Kampong Cham province. She strives for a living via rice farming and her paid working job. She has been involved in her current business for ages and it has generated her about 46,000 KHR per day.

This is the second loan for Kea's group consisting of four borrowers including Kea, who is the group leader. The past loan, which she has repaid back completely, has enabled her to uplift her lifestyle at a gradual pace.

Now she is applying for a new loan in order to buy fertilizer and rice seed for her crop. She hopes that she can gain a good yield, better than before.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and rice seed for her crop

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Cheung Prey district

loans.name: Yoeurng's Group

texts.en: Yoeurng, 33, lives in Kampong Cham province where she struggles at rice farming on two hectares of land to support her three children who remain in school. She supplements her income by working for a salary at a construction site. Yoeung and the other member of her loan group are requesting their first loan. As leader, she will spend her entire loan portion to buy fertilizer and rice seeds for her farm. She firmly believes that she can grow a larger crop and earn a larger income.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and rice seed for her crop

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Cheung Prey district

loans.name: Kulangwa Group

texts.en:
Said, who is in his 40's, is married and has two sons and two daughters; all them are at school. He is also taking care of his elderly parents. 

Said is a businessman who has engaged in this industry since he finished primary school 20 years ago. He manages a general store selling rice, maize and baking flour, cooking oil, juices, soda, match boxes, sugar, salts and so on. He runs his enterprise from 08 am to 09 pm daily, and is able to make a good profit each month. 

This is his eleventh loan request from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the previous loans (all of which were paid back successfully) to replenish his shop with more new demanded products, and bought a motorbike to support taking stock from where he purchases it. 

He is really doing great, and thanks Kiva for the support showing to third class people. Said received a profit, and it really helped him to build a house where he is living now with his family. Said covered part of school fees and household expenses. 

He dreams that one day he will be able to manage a wholesale shop. 

He will share this loan with his loan group, Kulangwa, which totals six members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy new inventory (sugar, maize flour, baking flour, cooking oil, rice, and juices) in large quantities.

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is a 22-year-old single man; he describes himself to be ambitious. He operates a transport business where he transports customers using his motorcycle. He has been involved in this business for four years. His business is located in a suitable location, and his primary customers are various travelers. 

James will use the Kes 40,000 loan to buy riding gear (i.e leather jacket and trousers). 

His business goal is to own several motorcycles within five years. He hopes that in the future, he will have a suitable business. 

This is his second loan with SMEP Micro Finance Bank. the previous loan was repaid successfully. 

He will use the anticipated profits to buy an extra motorcycle.

loans.use: to buy riding gear (i.e leather jacket and trousers)

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en:
Rosemary is 50 years old and lives in the town of Bombo in the Luwero region of Uganda. She is married and has 8 children, with 4 of them currently in school. For the past 3 years, Rosemary has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells essential commodities. 

To help expand her business, Rosemary has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more essential goods like sugar and salt for the business, and will help Rosemary to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children. Rosemary hopes that in the future she will be able to expand the business into a supermarket. 

Rosemary is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Rosemary who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more essential goods like sugar and salt for the business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buy a stock of rice and baking flour for preparing food to sell

loans.name: Mario

texts.en:
Mario previously accessed a 25,000 PHP loan. He utilized the loan to purchase beauty and hair products for his salon. His earnings were a big help in his personal, household, and business expenditures.

To help him continue operation of his business, he is now requesting a Php 30,000 loan to buy more beauty and hair products for his salon. His profits from the business will definitely help cover his daily needs. He looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in his heart.

Mario hopes that his business will continue to cover his everyday needs and that he will always be able to help his family. He meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies. * All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for beauty and hair products for his salon.

loans.name: Kalep

texts.en:
Kalep previously accessed an Rp 18.940.000 loan that he used to purchase green technology products to sell in his community. He successfully sold around 50 technologies in his first five months and more than doubled his earnings.

To help him continue operating his business, he is requesting another Rp 10.000.000 loan. He will use the loan to buy more stock of green technology products and provide solutions to his customers’ problems: difficult access to clean water, unaffordable LPG gas which make them to choose between three stone fire or kerosene stove, and frequent power cuts.  

Kalep is grateful for the support to increase earnings to cover his personal, household and business expenditures.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for his technology kiosk

loans.name: Libertina

texts.en:
Libertina previously accessed an Rp 3.000.000 loan to purchase green technology products to sell in her community. She successfully sold around 10 technologies in two months and more than doubled her earnings.

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting another Rp 10.000.000 loan. She will use the loan to buy more stock of green technology products and provide solutions to her customers’ problems: difficult access to clean water, unaffordable LPG gas which make them to choose between three stone fire or kerosene stove, and frequent power cuts.  

Libertina is grateful for the support to increase earnings to provide better education for her children.

loans.use: to help introduce simple, clean energy products to her community

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel previously accessed a Rp 7.000.000 loan to purchase green technology products to sell in his community. He successfully sold around 20 technologies in his first four months and was very pleased with his increased earnings.

To help him continue operating his business, he is requesting another Rp 10.000.000 loan. He will use the loan to buy more stock of green technology products and provide solutions to his customers’ problems: difficult access to clean water, unaffordable LPG gas which make them to choose between three stone fire or kerosene stove, and frequent power cuts.  

Daniel is grateful for the support to increase earnings to cover his personal, household and business expenditures.

loans.use: to pay for clean energy products that will be sold to his community

loans.name: Johannis

texts.en:
Johannis previously accessed a Rp 10.000.000 loan to purchase green technology products to sell in his community. He successfully sold over 30 technologies in his first three months and more than doubled his earnings.

To help him continue operating his business, he is requesting another Rp 10.000.000 loan. He will use the loan to buy more stock of green technology products and provide solutions to his customers’ problems: difficult access to clean water, unaffordable LPG gas which make them to choose between three stone fire or kerosene stove, and frequent power cuts.  

Johannis is grateful for the support to increase earnings to cover his personal, household and business expenditures.

loans.use: to sell simple, life-saving technologies  to his community.

loans.name: Marthen

texts.en:
Marthen previously accessed an Rp 5.000.000 loan to purchase green technology products to sell in his community. He successfully sold around 15 technologies in his first four months and is very pleased with the increase his earnings.

To help him continue operating his business, he is requesting another Rp 10.000.000 loan. He will use the loan to buy more stock of green technology products and provide solutions to his customers’ problems: difficult access to clean water, unaffordable LPG gas which make them to choose between three stone fire or kerosene stove, and frequent power cuts.  

Marthen is grateful for the support to increase earnings to cover his personal, household and business expenditures.

loans.use: to introduce simple, life-saving technologies such as solar lamps, water filters and clean cookstoves to his community.

loans.name: Noeh's Group

texts.en: Noeh’s group live in a rural village in Prey Veng province in Cambodia. Noeh makes a living cultivating rice with her family and she also does extra work as farm laborer to support her family. In their village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water.  Having a water filter at home will help each of these women to safeguard the health of their families and save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

loans.use: To buy a water filter to provide safe drinking water for their family.

loans.name: Sabita

texts.en:
Sabita is an energetic and enterprising woman of 38 years.  She is married, a housewife and a loving mother of two children (one son and one daughter).  Their daughter is in grade 9 and their son has completed his education and is unemployed. Sabita has an education up to grade 7. She can sign her name and her husband is illiterate and cannot sign his name.They live in their own house in Bhowalpara in Jalpaiguri district.

Sabita's husband is a farmer by trade.  He has been busy growing a variety of vegetables, mainly potatoes, chillies and beans.  He has great experience in this field.  He works hard from early morning till dusk to strengthen his family's economy, but he can't.  His main challenge is food and his daughter's education. Sabita helps her husband in his agricultural work while managing her household. They want to expand their business and have chosen bitter gourd for cultivation in their farmland. Bitter gourd is widely used in India so they hope to have a good profit from it.

So, Sabita has taken a loan from Kiva’s partner, BJS to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other necessary agricultural supplies to start the cultivation. She is hopeful that the business will be a lucrative one which will earn more revenue for their family's betterment.

She dreams of progressing in her business and purchasing more land in future with the profit.  She will be very much grateful to BJS and Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers and other necessary agricultural supplies to cultivate bitter gourd.

loans.name: Mao's Group

texts.en: Mao’s group live in a rural village in Prey Veng province in Cambodia. Mao makes a living cultivating rice with her family and she also extra works as farm laborer to support her family. In their village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water.  Having a water filter at home will help each of these women to safeguard the health of their families and save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

loans.use: To buy a water filter to provide safe drinking water for their family.

loans.name: Savon's Group

texts.en: Savon’s group live in a rural village in Prey Veng province in Cambodia. Savon makes a living cultivating rice with her family and she also does extra work as farm laborer to support her family. In their village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water.  Having a water filter at home will help each of these women to safeguard the health of their families and save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

loans.use: To buy a water filter to provide safe drinking water for their family.

loans.name: Saraswati

texts.en:
Saraswati lives in the small village of Kothapara in Jalpaiguri district.  She lives there with her husband and two sons who are students.  She is 47 years old and studied up to grade 5.  Her husband, who is 55 years old, is a farmer by trade.  He is illiterate and can sign his name only. Their sons are in grade 10 and grade 7.

Saraswati's husband has been farming for the last 15 years. The rich soil of the area where they live has made it good farmland.  So currently he is producing different kinds of vegetables like potatoes, beans, gourds, onions etc.  He is a hardworking and honest man, to whom his family's wellbeing is the first priority. So he tries hard to grow good crops so that he can satisfy his customers. His customers are also very happy with his polite behavior and the quality produce he sells.  Now, to grow his business in order to provide financial sustenance, he wants to cultivate bitter gourd which is a vegetable, having much demand in their region and profitable, too.

So, Saraswati has asked for a loan from BJS to purchase agricultural supplies such as seeds, fertilizers and pesticides. They hope to get good revenue from this loan to fulfill all their dreams, such as good education for their children, and to save money to build a better house in future.

Saraswati is thankful to BJS and Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase agricultural supplies for cultivating bitter gourds.

loans.name: Sahida

texts.en:
Sahida is a woman of 45 years who is energetic and enterprising.  Her family consists of her husband Mijammel, 52 years, and one daughter who is in grade 8.  Sahida is illiterate, but can sign her name, but her husband is unable to sign his name.  They live in Magurmari in the district Jalpaiguri.

She and her husband both are engaged in a business of buying and selling cows, the job they have been doing for the last few years.  They used to buy cattle from local wholesalers and sell them to the local people after raising them.  They want to grow the business by purchasing more cows in order to earn money to support the family. Unfortunately they don't have sufficient capital to purchase more cows to strengthen the business.

Sahida heard about Kiva’s partner, BJS, and asked for a loan from them to purchase more cows. Their village has a good pasture for livestock.  They have decided to get involved in fattening the cattle and selling them to the buyers. In this way they will upgrade their livelihood.

Sahida hopes that she will get the chance to improve their business and solve the family's financial problems. She wants to purchase more cattle with the profit to make a cattle herd.

She is grateful to the lenders.

loans.use: To purchase a cow for their existing business.

loans.name: Viviana Esther

texts.es:
Viviana es una joven emprendedora de 30 con grandes sueños y esperanzas en un negocio de alojamientos que tiene en su casa.
Ella tiene un trabajo como distribuidora en una empresa reconocida pero ha decidido obtener algunos ingresos extra para mejorar la calidad de vida de sus padres ya que no tiene hijos y es soltera.
Ella es una mujer enfocada en sus objetivos y muy responsable con su trabajo, cosa que ha hecho que tenga muy bien reconocimiento en la región.
Ella solicita un aliento monetario para pagar dos meses de arriendo del negocio y comprar algunos activos como mesas de noche y algunas sillas para amoblar un poco mas la habitaciones.
Esta idea surgió al ver la necesidad que tenían los visitantes de buscar un lugar donde alojarse y es así como decide atreverse y arriesgarse con este proyecto.
texts.en:
Viviana, 30, is an enterprising young woman with big dreams and hopes for her lodging business, which she runs from her home. Viviana works as a distributor at a well known company but she has decided to earn some extra income in order to improve her parents' quality of life. She is single and has no children.
Viviana is focused towards her objectives and she is responsible at work, which has earned her a good reputation in the region. She is asking for a loan to pay two months rent of her business and buy some furniture such as night stands and chairs to better furnish the rooms.
This business idea came to her when she saw the need visitors had to find a place to stay and that's why she decided to take the risk with this project.

loans.use: to pay two months rental of her business and buy some actives to furnish the rooms.

loans.name: Pauline

texts.en:
Pauline is a married woman. She has one child. She describes herself to be ambitious. She operates a tailoring business where she makes clothes to sell. She has been involved in this business for eight years. Her business is located in a developing area. 

Pauline describes her biggest business challenge to be lack of finances. She will use the Kes 50,000 loan to buy a stock of tailoring materials. Her business goal is to have a successful business within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will have a stable business that will sustain the family. This is her third loan with SMEP Micro finance Bank. Her previous loans were repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy a stock of tailoring materials

loans.name: Vilma Esperanza

texts.es:
Vilma de 21 años de edad, los padres de ella con mucho esfuerzo lograron que pudiese cursar hasta un 5º grado, luego por la situación económica no le pudieron seguir dando el estudio y se dedico a trabajar en compañía de su madre y en ocasiones le ayudaba a su padre en la agricultura, su compañero de vida se dedica a trabajar en la agricultura y no se le hace difícil el desempeño de esta actividad, sus hijos están pequeños y uno en espera.

El préstamo que esta solicitando a CREDICAMPO, es para comprar abono, fertilizantes, herbicidas, pesticidas y pago de mano de obra que le ayuden en el cultivo de maíz.

Las aspiraciones a futuro son sacar adelante a sus hijos, darles el estudio y ampliar un poco mas la vivienda ya que su familia esta creciendo.
texts.en:
Vilma is 21 years old. With a lot of effort, her parents were able to send her to school until the fifth grade. Then, because of their financial situation, they were not able to continue her schooling. Vilma then began to work with her mother and sometimes she helped her father with the crops. Vilma's life partner also works in agriculture, which is something he is very good at. Their children are young and they have one child on the way.

Vilma is requesting this loan from CrediCampo to buy manure, fertilizers, herbicides and pesticides, and to pay for the labor to help with her corn crop.

Her aspirations for the future are to provide for her children, to give them an education, and to increase the size of her home because her family is growing.

loans.use: to buy manure, fertilizers, herbicides and pesticides, and to pay for the labor to help with her corn crop.

loans.name: Mahfuzakhon

texts.ru: Махфузахон способная швея, проживающая в городе Худжанд, ей 28 лет. Она занимается любимым делом - шитьем. Махфузахон на протяжении 3 лет предоставляет услуги швеи у себя дома. Она замужем, мать двоих детей в возрасте 5 и 7 лет. Младший ребенок ходит в десткий сад, а старший учится в школе. Ее муж обычный водитель и зарабатывает этим на жизнь. Махфузаон просит кредит в размере 3000 TJS. Ее дом нуждается в ремонте. Благодаря кредиту она сможет провести долгожданный ремонт и улучшить условия проживания. Она надеется на поддержку.
texts.en: Mahfuzahon is a capable seamstress living in the city of Khujand, and she is 28 years old. She sews for a living. For the last three years, Mahfuzahon has worked as a seamstress from her home. She is married and the mother of two children, ages 5 and 7. The youngest child goes to kindergarten, and the oldest is in school. Her husband is a regular driver and earns a living at it. Mahfuzahon requests a loan of 3000 TJS. Her home is in need of repair. Thanks to this loan, she can begin long-awaited renovations and improve their living conditions. She is hoping for support.

loans.use: renovate her house to increase her standard of living

loans.name: Jorge Elias

texts.es:
La humildad es un valor muy característico en la vida de Jorge, un hombre trabajador y responsable dedicado 100% a su familia y su sostenimiento.
El trabaja todos los días en actividades agrícolas que aprendió empíricamente desde hace 10 años y que le ha servido para sacar adelante a su familia con orgullo y valentía.
El se levanta desde muy temprano con la ilusión y el firme pensamiento de trabajar para progresar.
Solicita un préstamo para compra insumos agropecuarios como fertilizantes y elementos para el tratamiento de la tierra, de este modo podrá producir cultivos sanos y de buena calidad. Entre estos cultivos cabe destacar el plátano y la yuca que ha sido su producto estrella durante todos estos años.
texts.en:
Being unassuming is a defining value in Jorge's life. He is hard working and responsible and is 100% dedicated to his family and their maintenance. He works everyday performing farming activities which he learned from experience in the last 10 years and which have allowed him to provide for his family with pride and courage.
Jorge wakes up very early with hope and firm determination to work in order to progress. He is asking for a loan to purchase farming supplies such as fertilizers and other elements to prepare his land. In this way he will be able to produce healthy and good quality crops. Among these crops are bananas and yuccas, which have been his star product all these years.

loans.use: to purchase farming supplies and to prepare his land.

loans.name: Khosiyatkhon

texts.ru: Хосиятхон пожилая но еще активная женщина  в возрасте 65 лет. Она с высшим экономическим образованием и имеет 35-летний стаж работы по профессии. В данный момент она занимается собственным торговым бизнесом. Уже ровно два года как она занимается куплей и продажей тканей и материалов для пошива платьев. Ей помогает в этом деле ее дочь. Хосиятхон вдова и живет с дочерью и двухлетним внуком в районе Дангара. Ей сейчас необходимо увеличить ассортимент товара и привезти сезонные ткани, чтобы увеличить количество продаж. С такой целью она запрашивает кредит и надеется, что ее поддержат.
texts.en: Khosiyatkhon is an elderly but still active woman of 65. She has a higher education in economics and a 35-year career in her field. She is currently running her own business selling fabric for dresses, something she's been doing for two years now. Her daughter helps her with the business. Khosiyatkhon is a widow and lives with her daughter and two-year-old grandson in the Dangara region. She now needs to increase her diversity of inventory and bring in seasonal fabrics so that she can increase sales. With this goal in mind she is requesting a loan and hopes that you will support her.

loans.use: to buy seasonal fabrics to broaden her inventory

loans.name: Phanny's Group

texts.en:
Phanny is 46 years old and a married mother blessed with three children. For the sake of her entire household, a grocery selling business and her paid-working job during  her spare time are the only sources of income. It is the business that she has occupied for 28 years. Phanny is quite new to VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). 

She leads a group of two to get a first time loan in the amount of 1,000,000 KHR each. As the leader, she will spend her entire loan portion to buy more grocery items to sell. 

She hopes that this loan will replenish her business in a timely manner.

loans.use: To buy more grocery items to sell

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Tbaung Khmum district

loans.name: Tatevik

texts.en:
Tatevik is from Arjut village of Lori region; she lives with her parents. All the family works hard to earn a living. 

Tatevik's father is employed in the private sector; he works as a driver. Tatevik herself is an agronomist. She keeps cows, calves, and chickens, and cultivates haricots, potatoes and onions. With the help of her mother, Tatevik also keeps an orchard where different types of fruit trees are grown (cherry, plum, nut, apple and pear). They sell the agricultural products in the local market, which is an important source of income for the family. 

The family's agribusiness needs some investment to be ready for the new agricultural season, so Tatevik has applied for this loan.  A loan of USD 3,000 will help this young hard-working woman and her family greatly, enabling them to pay for six more calves for their livestock.

loans.use: to pay for six calves

loans.name: Tam's Group

texts.en:
Tam, aged 53 and a mother of three children, lives in the Srey Snom district of Siem Reap province. Together with her rice crop business, she also raises pigs as additional income. This is the fourth loan for Tam with VisionFund Cambodia (Kiva’s partner). She completely repaid her past loan and it has enabled her to upgrade her lifestyle gradually. 

Now, Tam leads her group, consisting of six borrowers, to get a new loan. The total amount for her entire group is KHR 2,000,000, of which KHR 200,000 KHR is Tam's loan portion. 

As the leader, Tam will spend her entire loan portion to pay for plowing fees and to buy fertilizer for her crops. She greatly believes that she can gain a good yield, better than before.

loans.use: to pay for plowing fees and to buy fertilizer for her crops.

location.town: Siem Reap Province, Srey Snom district

loans.name: Betty Elizabeth

texts.es:
Betty es una joven de 25 años, madre soltera, de una alejada comunidad del norte de Nicaragua. Cuenta con una pequeña finca de 1.4 hectáreas de café. A su corta edad es una mujer emprendedora y luchadora que, preocupada por el futuro de su pequeño hijo, lleva 5 años dedicándose a la caficultura. 

Betty enfrenta los desafíos de toda mujer en el campo, la falta de fondos para invertir y mejorar en el desarrollo de su finca. Sin embargo, las ganas de salir adelante y el amor hacia su pequeño, ha sido el motor que la impulsa a crecer día a día. Para este ciclo, ella está solicitando un financiamiento para la adquisición de fertilizantes y abonos que le permitan incrementar la productividad de su café y con ello los ingresos que le ayudarán garantizar el sustento de su hijo.

Esta mujer visionaria sueña con ampliar el área de su pequeña finca y producir café de alta calidad, para ello se esfuerza cada día a fin de mejorar sus ingresos y con ello las condiciones para ella y su hijo.
texts.en:
Betty is a 25-year-old young woman; she is a single mother from a remote community in northern Nicaragua. She relies on a small 1.4-hectare coffee farm. Even at her young age, she is an enterprising woman who, thinking of the future of her young son, has worked for 5 years in coffee farming.

Betty confronts the challenges that face any woman in the countryside: the lack of funds to invest and improve the development of her farm. However, her enthusiasm to get ahead and her love for her little one have been the motor that drives her to grow each day. For this season, she is requesting a loan for the purchase of fertilizer and compost that will let her increase the productivity of her coffee. This will also increase her income, which will help her ensure that she can support her son.

This visionary woman dreams of increasing the size of her small farm and producing high quality coffee. For this reason, she makes an effort all day long to increase her income and improve her and her son's living situation.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and compost to apply to her coffee plot

loans.name: National Group

texts.en:
John is a married man and a father of two school-age sons. He is in his early 30's, and supports his family by running a shop selling clothes and another business selling fruit. He has had these businesses for five years now, and is able to make a good profit each month. John opens his shop from 08:30 am to 09:30 pm daily. 

This is his fifth loan request from Tujijenge Tanzaniawhich, which he will use to buy a new stock of clothes for his shop. 

John used the previous loans (all of which were paid back successfully) to open his clothes business; prior to that he was only a fruit vendor. He earned a profit which he used to cover school fees and home food expenses. 

John dreams that one day he will be able to be an international business person. 

He will share this loan with his loan group, NATIONAL, which consist of five members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy a new stock of clothes for his shop.

loans.name: Gevinor Group

texts.en:
Josephine is the featured borrower of Gevinor group. She joined with the other group members to acquire a loan from Kiva field partner Al Majmoua because they have all became special friends since they left their hometown in the Philippines to seek a better income to support their beloved families.

Josephine is a 50-year-old married mother of four children. She has been working as a housekeeper in order to support her family back in the Philippines in developing their living. 

Josephine provides her children with a a good income in order to pay for their education.  Through her acquired loan, she will pay for their education, and some of their living expenses.

Josephine is the second lady standing at the far right side of the picture, Jovita is the second from the left, Marilyn is the first from the left, while llyn is the first lady at the far right side of the picture.

loans.use: To pay for her children's education, and some of their living expenses

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is a 37-year-old, married woman. She has two children, ages 10 years and 16 years. She describes herself to be ambitious. She operates a retail business where she sells clothes. She has been involved in this business for eight years. Her business is located in a developing area. She describes her biggest business challenge to be lack of finances. She will use the KES 50,000 loan to buy more stocks of clothes. Her business goal is to have a successful business within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will have a stable business that will sustain her family’s needs. This is her second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Her previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of clothes to sell.

loans.name: Keren Kesia
